post_text: Stay home and stay safe.
shared_text:
St. Charles County Public Health
April 10 at 1:01 PM ·

We’ve heard that some residents mistakenly believe that after they’ve self-quarantined for the recommended two weeks that they are in the clear from COVID-19 and can now gather with others who have done the same. Here are a few reasons why this is not the case:
1) Any time you interact with others, there’s a possibility for the virus to spread.
2) If the person you meet didn’t fully stay at home for the full two-week period, they could be asymptomatic and carry the virus. Asymptomatic means they haven’t shown symptoms yet and/or may never show symptoms, but can still infect someone else.
3) The “Stay Home Missouri” Order prohibits individuals from conducting non-essential activities, from having more than 10 people in any single space at one time and from close contact with others (less than 6 foot distance between you and others).

For more information, visit https://www.sccmo.org/2105/COVID-19 or call the St. Charles County COVID Information Hotline at 636-949-1899.

post_text: #FHSDFridayFact...In November, lower interest rates in the bond market provided an opportunity for FHSD to save on interest costs for a portion of its outstanding debt. The District offered for sale over $32 million of general obligation refunding bonds and received over $74 million worth of orders. That high demand for Francis Howell bonds, coupled with favorable market conditions, allowed the District to lower interest rates even further than initial estimates, and secure total cash flow savings of nearly $3.2 million. Read more: http://bit.ly/2P8XF5g
